awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Life with an RNA Genome
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will explore origins-of-life by studying the transition from a primordial world in which RNA served as the repository of biological information to the first cells with DNA-based genomes. Trainees will gain expertise with chromosome-scale synthetic biology, a rapidly developing technology with transformative capabilities. Educational components situated at the intersection of STEM fields, social sciences, and rhetoric will engage a broad cohort of students discussing pressing issues in ethics and governance and the themes that shape scientific inquiry. Outreach will involve production of new media accessible to non-experts paired with in-depth written companion articles.

Most theories of the origins-of-life posit an RNA world of self-replicating RNA molecules, followed by an RNA/protein world and possibly RNA-based protocells, and leading to present-day cells where RNA has been replaced by DNA as the information source. The transition from RNA to DNA is crucial, yet little is known about the constraints of RNA as a cellular genome. Although RNA-based cells no longer exist on Earth, RNA viruses may be remnants of pre-DNA life, and RNA life may exist elsewhere in the universe. This research will create new enabling technologies to launch artificial RNA chromosomes (ARCs) in bacterial and eukaryotic cells, characterize the physical stability of ARCs inside these hosts, measure the fidelity of information transmission to daughter cells, and finally provide evidence for the information capacity of RNA-based genomes. The ultimate goals are to establish ARCs as essential chromosomes within E. coli and S. cerevisiae (yeast) hosts. These cells would represent new forms of artificial life, which along with other novel and radically modified organisms (N/RMOs) are of great public interest. The current governance of N/RMOs will be surveyed, and ethics and governance principles that should guide future research will be recommended.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Major activities

 

In the first two years, we designed a bacterial system and tested its capability of replicating RNA molecules in vivo. The system consists of an arabinose-inducible Qβ-RdRp protein (Fig S1a) which recognizes and replicates RNA molecules with specific 5’ and 3’ sequences (termed as RQ sequences, meaning “replicable by Qβ-RdRp”) and a single-copy Bacterial Artificial Chromosome (BAC) serving as the ARC launcher which houses IPTG-inducible reporter cassettes such as the KanR gene flanked by the aforementioned RQ sequences (RQ-KanR) (Fig S1b). The RQ sequence used in this study is 134-nt (also termed RQ134) and has been shown to be efficiently replicated by Qβ-RdRp in vitro (Munishkin, Alexander V., et al. Journal of molecular biology, 1991). We expected this system to enable stable maintenance of variant ARC species in the presence of Qβ-RdRp, but it did not work as expected and the bacteria strains with RQ- KanR-launcher and functional Qβ-RdRp were unable to survive under Kanamycin pressure (Fig S1c). Throughout the third year of this project, we modified the previous ARC launcher design by replacing the 5’ and 3’ flanking sequences with sequences from wild-type Qβ bacteriophage genome of varying lengths. The ARC-launching system consisting of a constitutive T7 promoter and an Qβphage-flanked KanR-GFP reporter cassette was cloned into a low copy p15A backbone housing a rpsLWT-TetR double-selection cassette which confers sensitivity to Streptomycin and resistance to Tetracyclin. The KanR-GFP reporter cassette was cloned in both forward and reverse directions to later assess the launching efficiency from both the positive and negative strand RNA, defined according to the direction of the open reading frames. The launcher plasmids were linearized and in vitro transcribed, and the synthesized RNA transcripts were later expressed and translated in bacterial cell lysates. Qβ-RdRp core enzyme fused with E. coli host factors EF-Ts and EF-Tu (Qβ-RdRp-fusion) was constructed with a polyhistidine tag at the C-terminus and purified with nickel-based affinity column. We observed increased expression of Qβphage-flanked KanR-GFP ARC in vitro in the presence of spike-in functional Qβ-RdRp-fusion via increased GFP fluorescence signal, indicating Qβ-RdRp-dependent RNA replication of Qβphage-flanked ARC. Additionally, we co-transformed the Qβ-RdRp expressing plasmid and the ARC launching plasmid into BL21 Tuner (DE3) strain with genome-integrated IPTG-inducible T7 RNA polymerase and assessed ARC replication in vivo by measuring Kanamycin resistance and GFP fluorescence under different induction conditions. We demonstrated Qβ-RdRp-dependent increase of expression of Qβphage-flanked KanR-GFP ARC in vivo, as evidenced by the presence of GFP fluorescence and slight increase in cell viability under Kanamycin pressure on agar plates upon induction of functional Qβ-RdRp (Fig S3). 

 

Additionally, given that Qβ-RdRp favors shorter substrates (Mills DR, et al. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA, 1967) we hypothesized that short ARCs can work as “parasites” to distract and stall Qβ-RdRp from replicating its native genome during phage infection cycles, thus stopping phage infection in bacteria population. We constructed an ARC with RQ-flanked negative-sense ccdB (a bacterial protein that acts as a DNA gyrase poison, locking up DNA gyrase with broken double stranded DNA and ultimately causing cell death) driven by a T7 promoter, which not only sequesters Qβ-RdRp to prevent efficient replication of phage genome but also produces the killer protein CcdB once replicated and expressed upon phage infection, further suppressing phage reproduction (Fig S4a). We transformed the BAC carrying the ARC launchers into bacterial strains susceptible to Qβ bacteriophage and subsequently challenged these strains with Qβ phage. Upon Qβ phage infection, Qβ-RdRp is translated from wild-type phage genome and starts replicating its own genome as well as pre-transcribed ARC, at supposedly different efficiencies. We observed higher optical density of culture in strains with ARC launchers compared to strains transformed with empty vector controls (Fig S4b). Thus, we demonstrated that alternate host immunity could be achieved via two strategies: 1) replication competition by supplying a better ARC substrate to sequester Qβ-RdRps and prevent from replication of the viral genome; 2) conditional expression of negative-sense toxin gene upon Qβ phage infection.

 


Last Modified: 02/02/2024
Modified by: Kaihang Wang

Major activities

Journal of molecular biology, 1991).We expected this system to enable stable maintenance of variant ARC species in the presence of Q-RdRp, but it did not work as expectedandthe bacteria strains with RQ- KanR-launcher and functional Q-RdRp were unable to survive under Kanamycin pressure (Fig S1c). Throughout the third year of this project, we modified the previous ARC launcher design by replacing the 5 and 3 flanking sequences with sequences from wild-type Q bacteriophage genome of varying lengths. Additionally, we co-transformed the Q-RdRp expressing plasmid and the ARC launching plasmid into BL21 Tuner (DE3) strain with genome-integrated IPTG-inducible T7 RNA polymerase and assessed ARC replicationin vivoby measuring Kanamycin resistance and GFP fluorescence under different induction conditions. Proc Natl Acad Sci USA, 1967) we hypothesized that short ARCs can work as parasites to distract and stall Q-RdRp from replicating its native genome during phage infection cycles, thus stopping phage infection in bacteria population. We constructed an ARC with RQ-flanked negative-sense ccdB (a bacterial protein that acts as a DNA gyrase poison, locking up DNA gyrase with broken double stranded DNA and ultimately causing cell death) driven by a T7 promoter, which not only sequesters Q-RdRp to prevent efficient replication of phage genome but also produces the killer protein CcdB once replicated and expressed upon phage infection, further suppressing phage reproduction (Fig S4a). We transformed the BAC carrying the ARC launchers into bacterial strains susceptible to Q bacteriophage and subsequently challenged these strains with Q phage. Upon Q phage infection, Q-RdRp is translated from wild-type phage genome and starts replicating its own genome as well as pre-transcribed ARC, at supposedly different efficiencies. We observed higher optical density of culture in strains with ARC launchers compared to strains transformed with empty vector controls (Fig S4b).
